description: pic - compile pictures for troff or TeX

global_flags.description: Recognize .PS, .PE, .PF, and .PY even when followed by a character other than space or newline.
Draw all lines using the \D escape sequence.  GNU pic always does this.
Operate in safer mode; sh commands are ignored.  This mode, enabled by default, can be useful when operating on untrustworthy input.
This is unnecessary because the troff output generated by GNU pic is device-independent.
Operate in unsafe mode; sh commands are interpreted.

Be more compatible with tpic; implies -t.  Lines beginning with \ are not passed through transparently.  Lines beginning with  .  are passed  through  with the initial . changed to \.  A line beginning with .ps is given special treatment: it takes an optional integer argument specifying the line thickness (pen size) in milliinches; a missing argument restores the previous line  thickness;  the  de‚Äê fault  line  thickness  is 8 milliinches.  The line thickness thus specified takes effect only when a non-negative line thickness has not been specified by use of the thickness attribute or by setting the linethick variable.

Don't use groff extensions to the troff drawing commands.  Specify this option if a postprocessor you're using doesn't support  these extensions, described in groff_out(5).  This option also causes pic not to use zero-length lines to draw dots in troff mode.
In TeX mode, draw dots using zero-length lines.

subcommands.name: As
subcommands.description: the  Encapsulated  PostScript File Format EPS is getting more and more important, and the conversion wasn't regarded trivial in the past you might be interested to know that there is a conversion tool named ps2eps which does the right job.  It is  much  better  than  the  tool ps2epsi packaged with gs.

subcommands.name: Boxes
subcommands.description: can have rounded corners.  The rad attribute specifies the radius of the quarter-circles at each corner.  If no rad or diam attribute is given, a radius of boxrad is used.  Initially, boxrad has a value of 0.  A box with rounded corners can be dotted or dashed.

subcommands.name: Concatenate
subcommands.description: and  write arguments to the standard error stream followed by a newline.  Each arg must be an expression, a position, or text.  This is useful for debugging.

subcommands.name: The
subcommands.description: troff  output  of pic is device-independent.  The -T option is therefore redundant.  All numbers are taken to be in inches; numbers are never interpreted to be in troff machine units.

subcommands.name: This
subcommands.description: syntax  resembles  variable assignment with = except that var must already be defined, and expr will be assigned to var without creating a variable local to the current block.  (By contrast, = defines var in the current block if it is not already defined there, and then changes the value in the current block only.)  For example, .PS x = 3 y = 3 [ x := 5 y = 5 ] print x   y .PE writes 5 3 to the standard error stream.

subcommands.name: To
subcommands.description: obtain  a stand-alone picture from a pic file, enclose your pic code with .PS and .PE requests; roff configuration commands may be added at the beginning of the file, but no roff text.

subcommands.name: are
subcommands.description: equivalent.  The commands to be performed for each line can also be taken from a macro defined earlier by giving the name of the macro as the argument to thru.  The argument after thru is looked up as a macro name first; if not defined, its  first  character  is interpreted as a delimiter.

subcommands.name: for
subcommands.description: i  between 1 and 9, are replaced by the i-th word of the line.  If filename is not given, lines are taken from the current input up to .PE.  If an until clause is specified, lines will be read only until a line the first word of which is  word;  that  line  will then be discarded.  X can be any character not occurring in body.  For example, .PS copy thru % circle at ($1,$2) % until "END" 1 2 3 4 5 6
